Research article TBD-grafted activated carbon as an efficient solid base catalyst for continuous Knoevenagel reaction Yi Chen Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization a Xueqing Ma Investigation a b Chenghao Zhang Investigation a Bingqi Xie Investigation a Wangyang Ma Investigation a b Jisong Zhang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a State Key Lab of Chemical Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China State Key Lab of Chemical Engineering Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China State Key Lab of Chemical Engineering, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China b College of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Hebei University of Science and Technology, Shijiazhuang 050018, China College of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Engineering Hebei University of Science and Technology Shijiazhuang 050018 China College of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Hebei University of Science and Technology, Shijiazhuang 050018, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The development of a highly efficient and stable metal-free solid base catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction remains a significant challenge. In this study, activated carbon is selected as support material to develop a new base catalyst due to its excellent chemical stability. A novel surface chloromethylation method is applied to modify the activated carbon surface, followed by covalent grafting of 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD), resulting in a highly effective solid organic base catalyst. A continuous platform based on a micro-packed bed reactor has been optimized for the Knoevenagel reaction. The system achieves excellent space-time yields (19129.4 g P r o k g c a t - 1 h - 1 ) and demonstrates a broad substrate scope. The solid organic base catalyst exhibits a turnover frequency (TOF) exceeding 140 h - 1 , surpassing the performance of similar nitrogen-based catalysts reported in literature (7.6–68.0 h - 1 ). Moreover, the catalyst shows no signs of deactivation after more than 23 h of continuous operation with a turnover number (TON) exceeding 115, indicating comparable performance reported in literature (29.7–297.2). Catalyst deactivation is primarily attributed to the adsorption of raw materials and products onto the base sites, leading to a gradual loss of catalytic activity. Keywords Surface modification Heterogeneous catalysis Knoevenagel reaction Activated carbon Micro-packed bed reactor Continuous flow Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The carbon-carbon bond-forming reaction plays a pivotal role in the synthesis of fine chemicals, with the Knoevenagel reaction being one of the most notable examples [1]. This reaction finds extensive applications in the synthesis of functional polymers [2], pharmaceuticals [3] and natural products [4]. It involves the dehydration condensation of aldehydes or ketones with active methylene compounds under the catalysis of a Brønsted weak base. In a recent comprehensive review [5], a class of metal-free nitrogen-based catalysts were extensively discussed. The lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom in these catalysts is highly effective at abstracting the active hydrogen from methylene compounds. This category of catalysts includes nitrogen-rich basic porous organic polymers (POPs) [6], biocatalysts [7], amine-functionalized mesoporous silica [8], mesoporous carbon nitrides [9], and amine-grafted activated carbons [10,11]. These catalysts not only exhibit high catalytic efficiency and excellent yields but also offer the added benefit of being metal-free, making them environmentally friendly compared with homogeneous base catalysts. Due to these properties, nitrogen-based catalysts represent a highly promising class of catalysts for future applications. Surface-modified activated carbon catalysts have attracted interest due to their tunable active sites and the exceptional chemical stability of the carbon support. By employing advanced surface modification techniques and innovative grafting methods, molecules such as 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) have been covalently attached to activated carbon surfaces [12–14]. The improved activity and stability of the catalyst are attributed to the stable support material and the diverse surface modification techniques. Activated carbon prevents the structural collapse often observed in silica-based materials [15] and mitigates the swelling issues commonly encountered with polymers in highly polar solvents. Despite the promising potential of surface-modified activated carbon catalysts, their application in the Knoevenagel reaction remains relatively underexplored. This limitation arises primarily from the constraints of traditional surface modification techniques for activated carbon, which often restrict the range of grafted molecules. Common modifications, such as the introduction of carboxyl [16,17] and aldehyde groups [14], are most effective when coupled with primary amines. However, these reactions often consume the exposed amino functional groups, substantially reducing the basicity of the grafted molecules, which is detrimental to their performance in base-catalyzed systems. Recently, the diazonium coupling process was applied to functionalize commercial activated carbon with various amines. Replacing phenyl primary amine [10] with 4-(1H-Imidazol-1-yl) aniline [11] significantly improved the yield to 80 %, surpassing homogeneous catalysts and highlighting the importance of selecting suitable nitrogen-containing basic molecules to enhance catalyst activity and durability. The ongoing development of nitrogen-containing heterocyclic bases presents promising opportunities for designing more efficient and stable catalysts. For instance, researchers successfully grafted 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD) onto the polyetheretherketone (PEEK) fiber and applied it in the Knoevenagel condensation of salicylaldehyde with malononitrile [18,19]. Selecting organic base with stronger basicity is an effective approach for designing efficient solid base catalysts. The key challenge is to successfully graft TBD onto activated carbon surfaces to develop high-performance catalytic systems. Compared to diazonium coupling, chloromethylation offers significant advantages as a modification method, allowing nucleophilic substitution with a broader range of functional groups, including primary, secondary, and tertiary amines, as well as nitrogen-containing heterocycles. Essentially, this approach better preserves the basicity of the grafted species. However, studies on the chloromethylation of activated carbon surfaces are still limited. A two-step process for preparing chloromethylated activated carbon has been reported [20]. Nevertheless, their approach is complex and time-consuming, relying on metal salt catalysts that not only complicate the procedure but also pose environmental concerns due to potential pollution. Given these challenges, there is an urgent need to develop a simpler and more efficient chloromethylation method for activated carbon. Such a method would greatly broaden the applicability of activated carbon-based catalysts in base-catalyzed systems, facilitating their use across a wider range of chemical reactions while avoiding the environmental drawbacks associated with metal-assisted processes. Chemistry in continuous-flow is an important process intensification strategy in organic catalytic synthesis, offering numerous advantages such as rapid condition screening/optimization, easy scalability, enhanced operational safety, and automation with possible addition of in-line reaction analysis [21]. The application of continuous-flow technology in the Knoevenagel reaction has been widely reported [22,23]. The principles of green chemistry have driven a shift toward continuous flow processes using heterogeneous catalysts [24]. In this approach, the catalyst remains fixed within the reactor while reactants flow continuously through it, enabling the reaction to proceed without requiring catalyst separation from the final product. This method eliminates concerns about catalyst residues affecting product quality and significantly minimizes catalyst deactivation and loss. Researchers have successfully applied various flow-based microreactors, including monolithic reactors [8,25], packed-bed reactors [26,27], membrane microreactors [28] and other reactors [29,30] for the Knoevenagel reaction. These systems provide remarkable efficiency improvements over traditional batch methods. Likewise, micro-packed bed reactors have demonstrated exceptional performance in hydrogenation [31,32] and oxidation [33,34] reactions. Due to the reduction in the particle size of the packed beads, the specific surface area increases rapidly, and internal diffusion resistance decreases. As a result, the micro-packed bed reactor demonstrates significant advantages in accelerating gas-liquid [35,36] and liquid-liquid [37,38] mass transfer. This large specific surface area also holds great potential in enhancing liquid-solid mass transfer. The combination of advanced heterogeneous catalysts with micro-packed bed reactors in continuous flow production setups holds great promise. This integration can further improve multiphase catalytic efficiency and prolong heterogeneous catalyst lifespan, offering a pathway to more sustainable and efficient industrial chemical processes. In this work, a novel single-step chloromethylation method for the surface modification of activated carbon without external catalysts is introduced. This innovative strategy enables the covalent grafting of organic bases, leading to the development of highly efficient solid catalysts. The resulting TBD-functionalized activated carbon materials are thoroughly characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), infrared spectroscopy (IR), elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TG), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). A micro-packed bed reactor is employed in the continuous flow Knoevenagel reaction, providing a detailed assessment of the catalyst’s performance under flow conditions. The catalyst’s lifespan is systematically evaluated within the optimized operating window, and the underlying deactivation mechanisms are explored to guide effective regeneration strategies. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Activated carbons (AC, 250–300 μm) were purchased from Beijing Phaseflow Technology, Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Acetonitrile, cis-1,4-dichloro-2-butene, benzaldehyde, malononitrile, N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), phenolphthalein, alizarin yellow R and ethyl acetoacetate were obtained from Myrell Chemical Technology Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Ethyl alcohol, 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD), methylbenzene, p-methylbenzaldehyde, 4-nitrobenzaldehyde, heptaldehyde, 2-furaldehyde, ethyl cyanoacetate and triethylamine were supplied by Macklin Chemical Technology Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Nitrogen gas (N2, 99.9 %) was provided by Air Liquid China Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of TBD-functionalized activated carbons Surface chloromethylation of activated carbon. AC was immersed into deionized water and washed thoroughly for several cycles until no residual ash remained. The filtered solid was dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 12 h to completely remove water from the pores. Methylbenzene (30.00 g), pre-treated activated carbons (5.00 g) and cis-1, 4-dichloro-2-butene (5.00 g) were introduced into a round-bottom flask with a condenser, and the mixture was refluxed at 150 °C for 120 h. Subsequently, the solid was filtered out and washed with methylbenzene (3 × 20 mL). The obtained solid was dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 4 h and denoted as AC-Cl. Functionalization of AC-Cl with TBD. As shown in Fig. 1 , in the first stage, TBD (5.00 g) was suspended in acetonitrile, then the mixture was stirred for 30 min to form a homogeneous solution. After that, dried AC-Cl (5.00 g) was soaked into the above solution and refluxed at 83 °C for 8 h. After the reaction completed, the residual solid was collected by filtration and washed with acetonitrile to remove any trace of TBD. The solid sample was dried to constant weight at 85 °C under vacuum to gain AC-TBD. The TBD loading of the grafted material was determined based on the change in nitrogen content measured by elemental analysis. It was assumed that each chloromethyl group reacts with one TBD molecule through nucleophilic substitution, resulting in an immobilized TBD site and the release of one free HCl molecule. The loading capacity was calculated using the following equation: (1) N A C - T B D ( % ) = 1 g × N A C - C l % + 42.03 g / mol × C T B D 1 g + ( M T B D - M H C l ) × C T B D where N ( % ) represents mass content of nitrogen; C T B D represents the TBD loading (mmol/g); M (g/mol) represents the molar mass of TBD molecule or HCl molecule. 2.3 Typical procedure for Knoevenagel condensation in batch processing Knoevenagel condensation in batch processing was conducted in a round-bottom flask. A homogeneous solution of benzaldehyde and malononitrile, both at a concentration of 0.40 mol L−1, was prepared in acetonitrile with a total volume of 10.00 mL. After the solution was prepared, it was protected from aldehyde oxidation by sealing the flask with a nitrogen balloon. The mixture was then heated to the specified reaction temperature. Subsequently, a precise amount of catalyst was rapidly introduced, and the stirring speed was adjusted to 1000 rpm to ensure efficient mixing. Samples (50 μL) were withdrawn at regular intervals for analysis, while maintaining the nitrogen balloon to prevent oxidation. For each experiment, the total volume of samples taken did not exceed 0.5 mL, accounting for less than 5 % of the total reaction volume. This small volume reduction was considered negligible and did not significantly affect the kinetic data. 2.4 Typical procedure for Knoevenagel condensation in continuous-flow processing As shown in Fig. 2 , a continuous-flow processing platform was developed to evaluate the performance of heterogeneous catalysts. The setup included a plunger pump (Ou Shi Sheng Technology Co. Ltd), a micro-packed bed reactor, a pressure regulator, an oil bath and necessary tubing components. A certain amount of solid organic base catalysts was packed into the micro-packed bed reactor (diameter 4.30 mm, length 13.0 cm). The flow rate was controlled by the plunger pump, while the pressure regulator was used to control the system pressure. A mixture of benzaldehyde (120 mmol, 12.73 g), malononitrile (120 mmol, 7.93 g), and acetonitrile (approximately 280 mL) was prepared in a flask and stirred at room temperature. Since benzaldehyde is prone to reacting with O2 in the air to form benzoic acid, which can poison the base sites on solid catalysts, the above mixture was protected by a nitrogen balloon during the experiments to prevent oxidation [26]. Acetonitrile as the solvent was first pumped into micro-packed bed reactor, while the oil bath was maintained at the desired reaction temperature. This step ensured that the catalyst surface was sufficiently wetted and any residual gas in the reactor was drained. After establishing a stable flow, the reaction mixture was pumped into the system at varied flow rates. The reaction products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC-8860) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an HP-5 capillary column (0.25 mm diameter, 30 m length). Aldehyde is considered the key reactant for calculating the conversion and selectivity of the target molecule, which are defined as follows: (2) Conversion % = C B A 0 - C B A C B A 0 × 100 % (3) Selectivity % = C P r o C B A 0 - C B A × 100 % (4) Yield % = C P r o C B A 0 × 100 % where, C B A 0 is the initial concentration of benzaldehyde, C B A is the concentration of benzaldehyde, and C P r o is the concentration of the target product at a given reaction time during the reaction. Turnover number and turnover frequency were defined as: (5) TON = n p n C a t (6) TOF = n p t × n C a t where n p represents the converted mole number of benzaldehyde, n C a t is the mole number of TBD immobilization on the catalyst, and t is the total reaction time. The space–time yield (STY) was defined as: (7) STY = C B A 0 × F L × M B A × Y i e l d ( % ) m C a t where, F L represents the flow rate, M B A represents the molar mass of benzaldehyde, and m C a t represents the mass of the solid base catalyst used. The residence time ( τ ) was calculated as: (8) τ = π × d 2 × L × ε 4 × F L where, d and L are the inner diameter and length of the micro-packed bed reactor, respectively, and ε is the bed porosity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts As shown in Fig. 3 (a), infrared (IR) spectroscopy was employed to confirm the covalent bonding between TBD and activated carbon. All samples were carefully dried before analysis. The IR spectra of these samples exhibited similarities, but with distinct differences in the intensity of characteristic peaks corresponding to specific functional groups. These variations provided key insights into the chemical interactions between TBD and the activated carbon surface. Notably, adsorption bands at 725 cm−1, which corresponds to C-Cl bond bending vibrations, was significantly enhanced in AC-Cl sample compared to AC, confirming the successful chloromethylation of activated carbon surface [39]. In the AC-TBD spectrum, this peak diminished or even disappeared, indicating that the chlorine atoms were substituted by nucleophiles, leaving the solid system and confirming the grafting of TBD on to the activated carbon. Conversely, the peak at 1206 cm−1, associated with C-N stretching vibrations [12], showed a marked increase in the AC-TBD sample compared to the other two, confirming the formation of new C-N bonds and indicating that TBD was effectively grafted onto the surface. Additionally, the adsorption peak at 1570 cm−1, representing C=N stretching vibrations, was significantly enhanced in the AC-TBD spectrum [40]. This peak is closely associated with the C=N structure in the TBD, providing compelling evidence for the successful incorporation of TBD onto the activated carbon surface. It is noteworthy that the C-N and C=N bond signals were observed in the initial activated carbon, likely attributed to the inherent nitrogen content of the material. This observation was further supported by XPS analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectra were further employed to confirm the successful covalent grafting of TBD molecules onto the surface. As shown in Fig. 3(b), a new Cl 2p signal appeared in AC-Cl, indicating the formation of chloromethyl groups on the activated carbon surface. In AC-TBD, a distinct N 1s signal was observed, suggesting the successful introduction of nitrogen-containing molecules. The high-resolution N 1s spectra of both AC and AC-TBD were deconvoluted, as shown in Fig. 3(c) and (d). Since no oxidative reagents were introduced during the surface modification and grafting stages, it is assumed that the absolute nitrogen N content remained unchanged. The increase in the absolute content of quaternary N and pyridinic N can be directly attributed to the presence of a quaternary nitrogen atom in each TBD molecule and the formation of new C-N bonds during the grafting process [41,42]. Similar results are also confirmed in the relative content, as shown in Fig. 3(e). This observation further supports the successful functionalization of activated carbon with TBD, highlighting the efficiency of the grafting method in introducing nitrogen-containing groups. The precise loading of TBD on activated carbon was determined through elemental analysis, as shown in Table 1 . By comparing the nitrogen content before and after grafting, the loading amount of TBD was calculated to be 0.84 mmol/g. This value reflects the efficient functionalization of activated carbon with TBD, confirming the successful grafting process and providing insight into the catalyst’s potential capacity for base-catalyzed reactions. The strengths of basic sites were determined by the Hammett indicator method, following the procedure reported in literature [43,44]. In detail, 100 mg of catalyst was shaken with 5 cm3 of a 0.1 % Hammett indicator solution in methanol and left to equilibrate. When an electrically neutral acid indicator is adsorbed onto a solid base from a nonpolar solution, the color of the acid indicator changes to that of its conjugate base, provided that the solid has sufficient basic strength to donate electron pairs to the acid. As shown in Fig. S1, the base strength of AC-TBD was found in the range of 9.3 < H_< 11.0. The TBD molecules have a base strength greater than 11.0, indicating that grafting results in a decrease in the basicity of the organic base molecules. This decrease is likely due to interactions between the activated carbon surface and the organic base. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted to further confirm that TBD was chemically grafted onto the activated carbon rather than being physically adsorbed. The TG curves for crude AC, AC-Cl and AC-TBD, shown in Fig. 3(f), reveal significant mass loss in the low-temperature range of 50–70 °C. This mass loss is primarily attributed to the desorption of adsorbed CO2, N2 and water vapor from the porous structures of the materials. For AC-Cl, a notable weight loss was observed at 215 °C, which is likely due to the degradation of chloromethyl functional groups, potentially releasing HCl or other chlorine-containing byproducts [45,46]. Essentially, the boiling points of the reagents used in synthesizing AC-Cl, toluene and cis-1,4-dichloro-2-butene, are 110.6 °C and 152 °C, respectively, both considerably lower than the observed mass loss temperature. This strongly indicates that successful chloromethylation has occurred on the activated carbon surface, confirming that the newly introduced chlorine is not merely physically adsorbed. The formation of covalent bonds substantially enhances the thermal stability of the material. Similarly, for AC-TBD, a significant weight loss was observed at 398 °C, likely corresponding to the cleavage of C-N bonds and the volatilization of TBD. This confirms that TBD is covalently grafted onto the activated carbon surface, as the degradation temperature (398 °C) is much higher than the boiling point of TBD (222.3 °C). The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77 K for the three materials are presented in Fig. 4 (a). The isotherms exhibit similar profiles across all samples, with a sharp increase in adsorption at low pressures, indicative of the filling of micropores. At P/P0 values above 0.90, the isotherms demonstrate a steep rise, suggesting a significant presence of macropores in the materials. These observations are supported by the pore size distribution profiles calculated using density functional theory, as shown in Fig. 4(b). The profiles reveal that the materials are primarily composed of micropores with diameters less than 2 nm, along with mesopores and macropores exhibiting a broad distribution extending beyond 30 nm. Table 2 summarizes the pore structural parameters for the three materials. Notably, after surface chloromethylation, both the specific surface area and pore volume of AC-Cl exhibited substantial reductions, with the introduction of chloromethyl groups leading to a contraction of the micropore structure. Following the grafting of TBD, the specific surface area and pore volume of the resulting material were diminished to 41.8 % and 40.7 % of those of the original activated carbon, respectively. The relatively larger size of TBD molecules results in the partial occupation of smaller micropores during the grafting process, thereby causing pore blockage. This effect becomes less pronounced as the pore diameter exceeds 1 nm, particularly in the mesopore and macropore regions (with diameters greater than 30 nm), where a significant reduction in pore density is observed. This observation suggests that the increased density of grafted TBD molecules within the larger pores enhances substrate diffusion toward the basic sites, thereby promoting the likelihood of reaction occurrence. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was employed to examine the morphological characteristics of the samples, as shown in Fig. 5 . The surface of AC exhibited a notably rough texture, characterized by numerous scars and a highly porous structure, with large micropores on the micron scale. After the incorporation of TBD, the surface roughness of the AC-TBD material was observed to decrease, accompanied by a reduction in pore density. This indicates that the grafting of TBD leads to the blockage of surface pores, which aligns with the findings from the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms. SEM-EDS mapping provides a clear visualization of the elemental composition and distribution on the surface. As shown in Fig. S2, the AC-Cl material exhibited a uniform distribution of chlorine elements. After TBD grafting, the AC-TBD material displayed a distinct and even distribution of nitrogen elements, with a concentration reaching 6.56 wt%. This suggests a high-density and uniform grafting of TBD onto the surface of activated carbon. 3.2 Catalytic performance of AC-TBD in batch processing The mechanism of the Knoevenagel condensation has been extensively studied in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, generally classified into two main pathways. In the first pathway, when the catalyst possessed adequate basicity, it abstracts an active hydrogen from the methylene compound, forming a carbon anion intermediate [47]. Conversely, when the catalyst exhibits weaker basicity, the reduced equilibrium constant restricts the formation of high concentrations of carbon anions [48]. Under these conditions, the reaction initiates with the condensation of the aldehyde or ketone with the basic catalyst, leading to the formation of an ammonium cation. Water or weak acid facilitates this process by promoting proton transfer, which generates hydroxide ions. Notably, acidity is a key influencing factor in this step. Only solvents with acidity equal to or stronger than that of water are capable of promoting the reaction. These ions increase the basicity of the active methylene compound, leading to the formation of an enol intermediate. This intermediate then undergoes an addition–elimination reaction, resulting in the formation of the target product. The first mechanism necessitates the use of a solvent that stabilizes the carbon anion, preventing its deactivation through proton transfer. In contrast, the second mechanism requires a solvent like water or weak acid that stabilizes the ammonium cation and facilitates proton transfer. Consequently, the selection of an appropriate solvent is critical for optimizing reaction rates and ensuring the stability of the catalyst. Several common solvents were selected for examination in batch reactions. As summarized in Fig. 6 (a), the reaction rate was slowest in the nonpolar solvent toluene, increased in aprotic polar solvents, and fastest in protic polar solvents. This behavior can be attributed to the presence of active methylene compounds in ionic pairs or cluster forms in solvents with low dielectric constants, which promotes intramolecular recombination. In contrast, in polar solvents, the carbon anion is effectively stabilized, facilitating its increased mobility and accelerating the reaction. The above results demonstrate that, using AC-TBD as the catalyst, the reaction proceeds via the first pathway, where the catalyst’s basicity is stronger than that of the active methylene compound. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), a possible mechanism for the Knoevenagel condensation in aprotic polar solvents is proposed. Moreover, in protic solvents with acidity weaker than that of water, the solvent cannot spontaneously generate sufficient protons to accelerate the dissociation of the ammonium cation, thereby limiting the progression of the second pathway. This acceleration is likely attributed to strong hydrogen bonding between the solvent and the anion, which further enhances proton transfer and significantly accelerates the reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 7(b), a possible catalytic mechanism under the first pathway in protic polar solvents is proposed. In this scenario, hydrogen bonding between the solvent and the protonated catalyst in step (Ⅱ) and (Ⅳ) stabilizes the charged intermediates and facilitates proton transfer between the catalyst and reaction intermediates. In contrast, in aprotic polar solvents, the solvent can only stabilize the charged intermediates, while the energy barrier for proton transfer remains relatively high [49]. Recent literature has documented instances where Knoevenagel reaction occurs spontaneously without the need for a catalyst [50,51]. Utilizing pure ethanol or a mixture of ethanol and water as solvents at 75 °C resulted in yields exceeding 80 % within minutes, demonstrating the broad applicability of this approach to a wide range of substrates. To accurately evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity of the solid base catalyst, control experiments were conducted in the absence of catalyst, as summarized in Table S1. In the absence of a catalyst, a stable mixture of benzaldehyde and malononitrile in acetonitrile, toluene and DMF did not spontaneously yield the desired product. In contrast, when ethanol was used as the solvent, stirring the mixture for 12 h resulted in a yield of 95.47 %, demonstrating that ethanol significantly enhances the reaction rate and product formation. To minimize the impact of pump fluctuations during the transition to a continuous process, thorough mixing of the substrates and solvents was ensured prior to the reaction. In this context, the promoting effect of ethanol was also taken into account. However, considering factors such as cost and solubility, acetonitrile was selected as the solvent for the continuous flow process. This choice allowed for a clearer understanding of the role of the solid organic base catalyst in facilitating the reaction. In the solvent screening experiments, the AC-TBD catalyst exhibited strong catalytic activity. To adapt the reaction for continuous flow processing, the reaction temperature was progressively increased to accelerate the reaction rate and minimize excessively long residence times within the continuous flow system. Using acetonitrile as the solvent, the catalytic performance of AC-TBD under batch mode was thoroughly examined. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the reaction yield increased with time, following an approximately quadratic polynomial relationship. The yield rapidly reached 68.7 % within the initial 10 min, and the space–time yield (STY) was calculated to be 6357.7 g P r o k g c a t - 1 h - 1 . 3.3 Catalytic performance of AC-TBD in continuous flow processing Process optimization experiments under continuous flow conditions utilizing an efficient micro-packed bed reactor were conducted. The effects of reaction temperature, substrate concentration, residence time, and catalyst loading on conversion rates and selectivity were systematically investigated. By adjusting the oil bath temperature, the temperature within the micro-packed bed reactor was effectively controlled. Thanks to the excellent heat transfer properties of this reactor design, the temperature within the reaction system remained stable throughout the entire reaction process. Under continuous flow conditions, the catalytic condensation reaction of malononitrile and benzaldehyde was optimized using AC-TBD as the catalyst, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). At a fixed reaction temperature, the yield of benzylidenemalononitrile increased significantly with prolonged residence time. Conversely, when residence time was kept constant, the yield improved with rising temperature. Notably, at shorter residence times, the yield was more sensitive to temperature variations. However, when the residence time was extended to 6.0 min (corresponding to a flow rate of 0.1 mL/min), the influence of temperature changes on the yield became minimal, while maintaining a high level of conversion. These findings suggest that extending the residence time significantly enhances the reaction yield. The intrinsic activity of the catalyst under continuous flow conditions was evaluated after eliminating external diffusion effects. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the average reaction rate gradually increased with the increase of liquid superficial velocity. When the liquid superficial velocity reached 13.8 cm/min or higher, the average reaction rate leveled off, and the turnover frequency (TOF) reached a maximum of 147.7 h - 1 . The space–time yield (STY) reached a peak value of 19129.4 g P r o k g c a t - 1 h - 1 , which is three times of the STY value in the batch mode. Table 3 summarizes the catalytic activity of solid base catalysts prepared using different methods on various supports, with the condensation reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate serving as the model reaction for comparison. In batch reaction mode, the TOF values of most catalysts ranged from 7.6 to 35.5 h - 1 , whereas in continuous flow mode, the TOF values increased to 60–68 h - 1 , significantly higher than in batch mode. The solid base catalyst formed by grafting TBD onto the surface of activated carbon exhibited the highest TOF value of 147.7 h - 1 , more than twice of the reported values in literature. Compared with the commercially available catalyst SiliaBond Amine (WAX) (R52030B), AC-TBD delivered a higher product yield with a lower catalyst loading, further underscoring its potential for practical applications [52]. Compared with triethylamine, a commonly used homogeneous base catalyst in industry (Table 3, entry 9), AC-TBD achieved a comparable product yield under the same catalyst loading. This enhancement is attributed not only to the strong basicity of TBD itself but also to the advanced chloromethylation method applied to the activated carbon surface, which maximizes the retention of the inherent basicity of the initial molecules, thus improving the basicity of the solid catalyst. 3.4 Substrate scope To comprehensively assess the industrial applicability of this catalyst, a range of aldehydes and active methylene compounds were selected as substrates, and experiments were conducted under identical reaction conditions. The catalytic results for different substrates are summarized in Table 4 . The presence of nitro groups, as electron-withdrawing substituents, significantly enhances the reaction efficiency, contributing to the maintenance of high yields. These strong electron-withdrawing groups enhance the electrophilic nature of the carbonyl carbon, thereby facilitating nucleophilic attack by the carbanion [56]. However, their high reactivity also makes them prone to oxidation by oxygen, resulting in the formation of acids that can reduce the catalyst’s activity. Consequently, the yield remains comparable to that observed with benzaldehyde. Conversely, methyl groups, as electron-donating substituents, tend to reduce yields by dispersing the positive charge on the carbonyl carbon, thereby slowing the reaction rate with the carbanion [57]. On the other hand, furfural exhibited greater reactivity compared to benzaldehyde, achieving a 100 % yield. This highlights the catalyst’s versatility and effectiveness across a wide range of aromatic aldehydes. The catalytic conversion for aliphatic aldehydes was lower than that for their aromatic counterparts, primarily due to the inherently lower reactivity of aliphatic aldehydes. Moreover, the acidity of the active methylene compounds significantly influenced product yields. Because the electron-withdrawing ability of the carboalkoxy group in ethyl cyanoacetate is much weaker than the nitrile group in malononitrile, the yield decreased to 82.3 % when ethyl cyanoacetate was used as substrate 2. Similarly, the use of the less acidic ethyl acetoacetate resulted in a significantly lower product yield. This reduction can be attributed to the decreased rate of active hydrogen abstraction by the solid organic base, leading to a lower concentration of the reactive carbanion intermediate. The product yield was sensitive to the acidity of the active methylene compounds. Future work will focus on further optimizing the grafting strategy to enhance catalyst basicity and broaden its application scope. 3.5 Catalyst stability and deactivation The stability of heterogeneous catalysts is a critical factor in determining their feasibility for practical industrial applications. The inherent chemical stability of activated carbon, combined with the optimized grafting method that forms stable C-N bonds, contributes to the catalyst’s stability. As a result, the catalyst exhibits notable catalytic stability and demonstrates a commendable service life. Under optimized reaction conditions, the change in catalyst activity over time was assessed, as shown in Fig. 9 (a). The product yield remained above 95 % for the first 23 h but gradually declined with extended reaction time, dropping below 90 % after 44 h. It has been calculated that the turnover number (TON) is 118.0 while setting yield below 90 % as inactivation. As shown in Fig. S3, after deactivation, the catalyst could be successfully regenerated by washing with organic bases, restoring its catalytic performance. As summarized in Table 3, the TON values reported in literature are in the range of 29.7–297.2. While the catalyst demonstrates promising stability in catalytic performance, further improvements are needed to enhance its long-term durability. To identify the causes of catalyst deactivation, solvent washing experiments were performed in combination with elemental analysis to assess whether leaching of the active component contributed to the decline in activity. Acetonitrile was used as the solvent, flowing at a rate of 2.0 mL/min over 1.0 g of packed catalyst at 50 °C. Liquid samples were collected at the reactor outlet every hour and analyzed by gas chromatography. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the results indicate that prolonged solvent washing at high flow rates did not result in TBD leaching. Over a 4-hour period, no signals corresponding to TBD molecules were detected in the effluent, confirming that TBD was covalently immobilized on the support. This finding underscores the robustness of the covalent grafting method and offers valuable insights into potential causes of catalyst deactivation, suggesting that factors other than active component leaching may contribute to the decline in catalytic activity. Since the product yield remained relatively high during the long-term test, catalyst deactivation was further studied to induce activity shifts. To determine the inherent deactivation rate of the catalyst, a new test was conducted at higher liquid flow rates and substrate concentrations. As shown in Fig. 9(c), under conditions of 30 °C, 1.0 M benzaldehyde, and a liquid flow rate of 0.5 mL/min, the catalyst exhibited a rapid decline in activity within the first hour. After this initial phase, the catalyst underwent a slower, more gradual rate of deactivation. Additionally, the catalyst’s hot leaching test can indicate whether the reaction proceeds in a heterogeneous form and verify whether the grafted TBD molecules are easily leached out under the reaction conditions. As shown in Table S4, samples were taken at 120 min and 240 min of feeding and immediately analyzed using gas chromatography. After protecting the samples with nitrogen for 6 h, the tests were repeated. The resulting reaction conversion rates were nearly identical, with only a slight increase observed. These data suggest that, during the reaction, a minimal amount of TBD molecules may leach into the reaction liquid; however, their contribution to the overall reaction is negligible. Therefore, the reaction mechanism remains predominantly heterogeneous. As shown in Table S3, elemental analysis results indicate that the nitrogen content of the catalyst showed minimal change before and after deactivation, decreasing by only 0.3 %. This suggests that the grafted TBD molecules were only slightly lost during the reaction and are not the primary cause of catalyst deactivation. After ruling out TBD leaching as the cause, and based on literature concerning base-catalyzed systems, it was hypothesized that catalyst deactivation could be attributed to two factors: the covering of active sites [58] and the poisoning of basic sites due to the oxidation of benzaldehyde into benzoic acid [26], which leads to a decline in catalytic performance. After vacuum drying at 80 °C for 24 h, the deactivated catalyst was analyzed using nitrogen adsorption–desorption tests at 77 K, as shown in Fig. S4. This procedure aimed to evaluate any potential changes in the pore structure and assess whether the deactivation was related to pore blocking or alterations in the surface area. As summarized in Table S4, the data revealed that the specific surface area decreased significantly from an initial 641 m2/g to 510 m2/g, and the pore volume dropped from 0.48 cm3/g to 0.36 cm3/g. This indicates that a substantial number of small molecules accumulated in the catalyst’s pores, interacting strongly with the surface. The pore size distribution further supports this conclusion. A significant reduction in pore density was observed at a pore size of 0.8 nm in the deactivated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst. Given that the molecular size of benzaldehyde is approximately 0.65 nm, this suggests that benzaldehyde molecules likely accumulated in these pores, potentially due to the inherent hydrophobicity of the activated carbon. Additionally, mesopores and macropores larger than 40 nm also exhibited shrinkage and a decrease in pore density, likely caused by the adsorption of substrate and product. The Hammett indicators revealed that the AC-TBD catalyst had lost its basicity, as it could no longer turn phenolphthalein red. This observation further supports the proposed deactivation mechanism. A straightforward regeneration method for the catalyst involves washing with a small amount of a homogeneous weak base to remove raw materials and products that are strongly adsorbed at the active sites. Organic bases such as diethylenetriamine and triethylamine have proven to be effective in regenerating the catalyst. The high reactivity of the active sites and the large number of micropores in the support contribute to the catalyst’s limited lifespan. Future work should focus on further optimizing the basicity control of the catalytic sites and modifying the support’s pore structure for enhanced reaction performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, a simple method was developed to chloromethylate the surface of activated carbon using cis-1,4-dichloro-2-butene as a reactant, requiring only heating and no catalyst. Subsequently, 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD) was covalently grafted onto the activated carbon. XPS and IR analyses confirmed the formation of C-N bonds via nucleophilic substitution, and thermogravimetric analysis demonstrated the material’s excellent thermal stability. The TBD loading was found to be 0.84 mmol/g, as determined by elemental analysis. This strategy employs cost-effective activated carbon as the support while covalently immobilizing the expensive organic base, significantly reducing catalyst production costs. A micro-packed bed reactor was applied to the Knoevenagel reaction, significantly enhancing liquid–solid mass transfer and substantially improving reaction efficiency. The system achieved a peak space–time yield (STY) of 19129.4 g P r o k g c a t - 1 h - 1 , three times higher than that observed in the batch mode. The catalyst demonstrated a turnover frequency (TOF) of 147.7 h - 1 , considerably exceeding the reported values reported in literature. Furthermore, the AC-TBD catalyst maintained a stable yield of over 90 % for more than 43 h with a high TON value of 118.0. The main cause of catalyst deactivation is attributed to micropore adsorption and the strong interaction adsorption between the active sites and organic molecules. Future studies should focus on exploring effective strategies to mitigate catalyst deactivation and achieve long-term stable catalysis. This work provides valuable insights for the design of activated carbon-supported organic base heterogeneous catalysts, offering guidance for further catalyst development. coredata.dc:description: The development of a highly efficient and stable metal-free solid base catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction remains a significant challenge. In this study, activated carbon is selected as support material to develop a new base catalyst due to its excellent chemical stability. A novel surface chloromethylation method is applied to modify the activated carbon surface, followed by covalent grafting of 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD), resulting in a highly effective solid organic base catalyst. A continuous platform based on a micro-packed bed reactor has been optimized for the Knoevenagel reaction. The system achieves excellent space-time yields (19129.4 g P r o k g c a t - 1 h - 1 ) and demonstrates a broad substrate scope. The solid organic base catalyst exhibits a turnover frequency (TOF) exceeding 140 h - 1 , surpassing the performance of similar nitrogen-based catalysts reported in literature (7.6–68.0 h - 1 ). Moreover, the catalyst shows no signs of deactivation after more than 23 h of continuous operation with a turnover number (TON) exceeding 115, indicating comparable performance reported in literature (29.7–297.2). Catalyst deactivation is primarily attributed to the adsorption of raw materials and products onto the base sites, leading to a gradual loss of catalytic activity.
